Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Modeling Sediment Production from Glaciers off south-central Alaska during Quaternary Climate Oscillations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs will model the production, transport, and deposition of glacial sediments at the Alaska-Aleutian subducting margin during the last 125,000 years. The Cordilleran Ice Sheet and crustal response to ice loading will be modeled using the University of Maine Ice Sheet Model (UMISM). USISM solutions will be related to existing sediment datasets and glacial power erosion laws to determine temporal and spatial patterns of erosion and sediment distribution. Suspended sediment samples and field measurements of rock strength will be collected and integrated with the modeling efforts.

Broader Impacts:The societal impacts of the study ultimately include a better understanding of earthquake hazards along this active margin. The project will involve graduate and undergraduate students. Data and models will be simplified for online experimental learning modules targeted at K12/general audiences. Model results will be made available through the U Maine web server.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the largest sources of sediment to Earth’s oceans derives from the glaciated and tectonically active margin of South East Alaska where the Pacific plate is converging with the North American plate at rates similar to those of that form the Himalayas. This collision over the last 6 million years has produced the highest coastal topographic relief on Earth (the St Elias range), a vast temperate glacier system and repeat great earthquakes – all of which are related to the supply of sediments to the Gulf of Alaska. Modern erosion and sediment supply rates in South east Alaska are exceptionally high and are associated primarily with the intense and active glacial system. However, the modern glacial system, while extensive, is far smaller than it was during the past glacial maxima. Over the past 125,000years, the Cordilleran Ice Sheet has grown and shrunk in response to fluctuations in temperature and precipitation with the maximum extent occurring ~ 17000 years ago. Our research program has investigated the influence of this glacial fluctuation, with its effect on glacial erosion, together with the rock damage caused by the active tectonics, on erosion and sediment supply to the Gulf of Alaska.

To accomplish this, we have followed two primary and parallel research directions:

1)      Used the highest resolution climate information currently available to provide temperature and precipitation inputs to model the glacier dynamics in our University of Maine Ice Sheet Model (UMISM) over the past 125kyears (Figure 1). From our model, we can predict ice velocities, ice thickness and direction of glacial flow at annual intervals for the past 125kyears. These are the dominant glacial parameters that influence the manner and rate of glacial work done on the landscape and sediment supply for the adjacent basins. (see accompanying images)

2)      Developed a material strength surface map of Southeast Alaska using field and theoretical techniques, to allow calculation of the resulting landscape modification due to the fluctuating glaciers described in #1 above.  (see accompanying images)

3)      The primary outcomes of our parallel approach have been: A) produce the highest resolution glacier ice model for the past 125, 000 years in existence (model results available in netCDF format on request); (B) Characterize the material particle strength and fracture density at specific field locations of fault damage and undamaged zones; (C) Develop and employ a theoretical proxy estimation of fracture density over all of Southeast Alaska based on topographic fabric; and (D) Apply the high resolution glacial model in (1) to the spatially variable strength field of (2) to estimate realistic erosion rates, locations and sediment types from Southeast Alaska. (see accompanying images)

The resulting models show large divergence from erosion and sedimentation rates and patterns defined under the assumptions of constant ice flux and homogeneous rock strength. Our approach, though developed for Southeast Alaska is general in nature and can be applied to all of Earth’s glacio-tectonic regions.

Broader Impacts: In addition to the influence on general glacial erosion models of our work for the Earth Science community, several other broader impacts  have arisen from this project, including: the availability of our high resolution ice sheet model to understanding early human migration patterns in the northwest Pacific, identification and refinement of geohazards associated with both climate and seismic events, and outreach to the broader community via the UMaine Environmental Change Model (http://cci-reanalyzer.org/ECM/ )which was specifically upgraded during this project (see accompanying images).
